# Introduction

 At the first day of class there are 35 students in Math Statistics class and professor Brownlow always proposes this bet to his students "I will wager $2 to your bet of $1 that at least two people in today's class have  the same birthday.  He tells me he has made that bet 637 times so far. Where do you think his profits are? Discuss this in a markdown document
 
Report git commit structure:
There are 3 questions and there should be at least 3 separate commits, at least one dealing with each of the 3 questions.
1. What are the fair odds for a bet on matching birthdays in a 35 person class.
2. For what size class is a 2:1 odds bet fair.
3. How much money would Brownlow be expected to end up with if the bets went as described.

# What are the fair odds? Use manipulation of odds in the function to tune Brownlows earnings to zero. 


<!--Decide on your methods:  In this section explain the approach you will take to attack the issue --- how will you decide on a likely estimate of professor Brownlow's earnings or losses after 637 bets. Also explain how you construct a 95% confidence interval about your estimate of his winnings !-->

To determine the fair odds for Brownlowâ€™s birthday bet, we first calculated the probability that at least two people in a 35-person class share a birthday. Using the standard birthday-problem formula, this probability is about 81%, meaning the event occurs far more often than not. We then used a simple expected-value approach: Brownlow wins the studentâ€™s $1 whenever there is a match and loses his wager whenever there is no match. By setting Brownlowâ€™s expected earnings equal to zero, we solved for the payout that would make the bet fair. This showed that instead of risking only $2, Brownlow would need to risk about $4.39 per $1 bet to break even in the long run. We verified this using both a closed-form calculation and Monte-Carlo simulations, which also allowed us to construct a 95% confidence interval for his total winnings across 637 bets. Under Brownlowâ€™s current 2:1 payout, the expected value remains strongly positive, demonstrating that the existing odds heavily favor him.
